Title: Reel Love

reviewText: "Reel Love" is a slight, but not unappealing, flight of fancy that made its TV debut on the CMT (Country Music Television) network.  CMT isn't particularly well known for its dramatic lineup of original programming, so my expectations of the Leann Rimes headlined movie were fairly minimal.  That said, the movie has a pleasing tartness that made it far more enjoyable than I had imagined it would be.  While the plot lacks any originality or surprise, the actors are appealing and the screenplay has more wit than comparable TV productions.  So if you like these types of movies (and you know who you are), I'd say that "Reel Love" is worth a look.  If, however, you don't appreciate the schmaltz, sentimentality and predictability inherent in the genre--nothing in this film will alter your opinion.  While I was entertained throughout, though, I don't imagine that I'll be replaying this anytime soon for a second viewing.Rimes plays a successful big city attorney whose life is upended when news of her father's heart attack draws her home.  Home is a beautiful fishing village and father is a cantankerous Burt Reynolds, so you know you're in store for lessons about simple living and familial commitment.  Of course, the movie plays out as a comedy as Rimes readjusts to her more humble beginnings, but she has a surprisingly appealing comic touch.  As she banters with old friends and a potential love interest (Shawn Roberts), the dialogue is playful and fun.  Of course, the fact that Rimes already has a boyfriend poses an obstacle--but don't worry, he's portrayed as such a buffoon, we can't take anything very seriously.  He is more of a joke to be ridiculed than a real character.  Tensions run high, though, in a fishing subplot near the end of the movie that unites the town and makes our hometown girl a hero.  Can Rimes find true love?  Can she mend fences with a distant father?  Will she see the advantages of small town living?  If I have to answer any of those questions for you, you've obviously never seen a TV movie!Rimes, though, is very likable.  Although not given a lot to do, Roberts is equally appealing (even if he stands around with a self-satisfied grin most of the time).  And Reynolds does the most he can with a rather stock character.  Some might have a soft spot for "Reel Love."  If this review was for watching the movie for free on CMT, I'd say go ahead and give it a try.  You just might like it.  But as a DVD purchase, it plays to a particular audience.  If you fall within that audience, this is a recommendation.  If not, it doesn't push out of the expected format to make it particularly noteworthy or unique.  Pleasant for those that like TV movie romance.  KGHarris, 6/12.
summary: A Surprisingly Sassy TV-Movie Romance: A Lightweight Look At Fishing, Family And Falling In Love
Title: Reel Love

reviewText: LeAnn Rimes is one of my favorites.  This is a very nice story and well done...  Everyone in the family can and should enjoy this movie...  The ending is good and I think should remind each of us what is important in life.
Title: Reel Love

reviewText: Need another lightweight romantic comedy?  With LeAnn Rimes and good ol'boy veteran Burt Reynolds at the reigns or is it fishing reel?Up and coming lawyer(Rimes) rushes back to her country hometown at the news that her father(Reynolds) suffered a heart attack.  She crashes her yuppie boyfriend's snazzy car and meets the auto repairman, a potential, heartthrob of her life, maybe.There's lots of folksy humor and a bit of hero and heroine at odds romance as Rimes character deals with whipping her somewhat estranged father, whom only wants to fish, into shape, dealing with her career and boyfriend and getting back to Chicago vs. a developing love, getting to know her dad, and realizing what she may have been missing in her rush for success.Yes, yes, it's quite predictable, but the countryside is pretty, I think they shot it in Canada, and LeAnn Rimes can act; however, don't expect any singing.  She, also, wears the same outfit for most of the movie.  In the short extras, she states she was ready to burn it by the end of the shoot.It's a PG kind of movie by CMT, but the kids will be totally bored.  For adults seeking some mindless, RC escapism- I seem to need more and more of that lately.  3 1/2 stars.
Title: Reel Love

reviewText: I like LeeAnn Rimes and Bert Reynolds was funny as always.  This was a fun movie...  If you like some comedy, a little romance and the relationship of an ornery old dad with his insistent daughter, then you'll enjoy this one.
Title: Reel Love

reviewerName: The Movie Guy "Movies from A to Z"
reviewText: Holly (LeAnn Rimes) is a Chicago lawyer with a lawyer boyfriend Carl (Jeff Roop). Carl is given a typical Hollywood shallow personality. When Holly's dad (Burt Reynolds) has a heart attack while fishing, Holly returns home to help out, although her presence is not overly appreciated. While in route she wreaks her boyfriend's car, something he seems to care about more than her.While in town in Alabama Holly meets her old girlfriend from high school (Mary Ashton) and the proverbial hunky nice guy mechanic who works on her car (Shawn Roberts). There is also a record sized bass in the lake Burt calls "Queen of Sheba" and has been trying to catch. Christian Potenza plays Everett, Burt's son who likes his drink.This isn't "Tamara Drewe" funny. The humor is light as is the drama. It is a simple non-offending story that we might expect Doris Day to play the lead, a chick flick that may be viewed as a light romantic comedy with a fishing theme in an attempt to get males to watch it too.PARENTAL GUIDE: No f-bombs, sex, or nudity. Some implied nudity in a hot tub (all shoulder up) and some PG sex references.
summary: FRIENDS DON'T LET FRIENDS DIE FISHING
Title: Reel Love
